lg.l: A Lady wise, as well as Fair,
Whose Conscience always was her Care
Thoughtfull upon a point of Moment
Would know the Text, as well as Comment
So hearing of a grave Divine
She sent to bid him come, & Dine;
But you must know he was not quite
So grave as to be unpolite;
Thought Human Learning would not Lessen
The Dignity of his profession,
And if you heard the man discourse
Or preach you'd like him Scarce the worse──
He long had bid the Court farewell
Retreating Silent to his Cell
Suspected for the Love he bore
To one, who Sway'd some time before
Which made it more Surprising How
He should be sent for thither Now
The Message told── He gapes & Stares,
And Scarce beleives his eyes or Ears,
Could not conceive, what it should mean,
And fain would hear it told again,
But then the Squire so trim & nice,
'Tware rude to make him tell it twice;
So bow'd── was thankfull for the Honour
And would not fail to wait upon Her.
His Beaver brush'd, his Shoes, & Gown,
Away he Trudges into Town,
\P·over·B\asses the lower Castle yard,
And now advancing to the Guard,
He Trembled at the thought of State,
Too Conscious of a Sheepish Gate;
His Spirits of a Sudden fail'd him,
He stop'd── & could not tell what ail'd him──
What was the message I receiv'd,────
Why certainly the Captain rav'd────
To dine with her── & come at three────
Impossible── it can't be me──────
Or maybe, I mistook the Word──────
My Lady── it must be my Lord──
My Lord's Abroad── my Lady too──
What shall the unhappy Doctor do?
Is Captain C────·──de here pray── no──
Nay then tis time for me to go────
Am I awake, or do I dream,
I'm sure he call'd me by my name
Nam'd me as plain, as he could speak────
And yet there must be some mistake────
Why what a Iest should I have been.
Now, had my Lady been within?
What could I say── I'm mighty glad
She went abroad── she'd think me mad────
The hour of dining now is past
Well then, I'll e'en go home & fast
And since I Scap'd being made a Scoff
I think, I'm very fairly off.
My Lady now returning home
Calls C────de──── is the Doctor come?
He had not heard of him── pray see,
Tis now a quarter after three;
The Captain walks about & Searches
Thro'all the Rooms, & Courts, & Arches,
Examines all the Servants round,
In vain── no Doctor to be found!
My Lady could not Chuse, but wonder────
Captain, I fear, you've made a blunder;
But pray, to morrow go at ten,
I'll try his manners once again,
If rudeness be th'effect of knowledge,
My Son shall never see a College────
This Captain was a man of Reading
And much good sence, as well as breeding
Who loath to blame, or to incense,
Said little in his own defence.
Next day another Message brought──
The Doctor frighted at his fault,
Is dress'd, & Stealing thro' the Crow'd──
Now pale as Death! then blush'd──& bow'd──
Pausing── and faltering── hum'd & haw'd──
Her Ladyship was gone abroad────
The Captain too── He did not know──
Whether He ought to stay── or go──
Beg'd she'd forgive him── in Conclusion
My Lady pittying his Confusion
Call'd her good nature to releive him
Told him she thought she might beleive him,
And would not only grant his Suit
But Visit him, & eat some Fruit,
Provided at a proper time,
He told the real truth in Rhyme.
'Twas to no purpose to oppose──
She'd hear of no excuse in prose.
The Doctor stood not to debate,
Glad to compound at any Rate,
So bowing, seemingly comply'd
Tho' if he Durst, he had deny'd.
But first resolved to shew his Tast,
Was too refin'd to give a Feast,
He'd treat with nothing yt was rare,
But winding walks, & purer Air,
He'd intertain without expence,
Or pride of vain Magnificence;
For well he knew to such a Guest,
The plainest meats must be the best.
To Stomachs Cloy'd with Costly fare,
Simplicity alone is rare────
Whilst high, & nice, & curious meats,
Are really but Vulgar treats.
Instead of Spoils of Persian Looms,
The Costly boast of Regal Rooms,
Thought it more Courtly, & discreet,
To Scatter Roses at her Feet;
Roses of Richest Dye, that Shone
With native luster, like her own;
Beauty that needs no aid of art,
Thro' every sense to reach the heart.
The Gracious Dame altho she knew,
All this was much beneath her Due
Liked every thing── at least thought fitt
To praise par maniere d'acquitte────
But yet, tho' seeming pleas'd, can't bear
The Scorching Sun, or Chilling Air,
Frighted alike at both extremes,
W'he displays, or hides his Beams;
Tho' seeming pleas'd with all she sees,
Starts at the rustling of the Trees,
Can scarcely speak for want of breath,
In half a walk fatigued to Death!
The Doctor takes his Hint from hence
To vindicate his late offence:
Madam The mighty Power of use,
Now Strongly pleads in my excuse;
If you, unus'd have scarcely strength,
To move this walks uncrowded length,
If Startled at a Scene so rude
Thro' long disuse of Solitude;
If long confined to fires & Screens,
You dread the waving of those Greens;
If trees, that neither see nor hear;
Nor speak, nor walk, can give you fear;
If you, who long have breath'd the Fumes
Of City Fogs & Crowded rooms,
Do now Sollicitously Shun
The Cooler Air, & dazling Sun;
If Sols Majestick Eye you flee;
Learn hence t'·Excuse, & pity me.
Consider── what it is to hear
The powder'd Courtiers witty sneer;
To see th' important men of Dress
Snouching my College Aukwardness,
To be the Strutting Cornet's Sport!
To run the Gauntlet of the Court!
Winning my way by Slow approaches,
Thro' Crowds of Coxcombs & of Coaches,
From the first feirce Cockaded Centry
Quite thro' the Tribe of waiting Gentry!
To pass so many Crowded Stages!
And stand the staring of the Pages!
And after all── to crown my Spleen,
Be told── you are not to be Seen──
Or if you are── be forced to bear
The awe of that Majestick Air.
And can I then be faulty found,
In dreading this vexatious round,
Can it be Strange, if I eschew
A Scene so glaring, & so new!
Or is he Criminal, that flies
The living Luster of your Eyes!
